quoteFirst: There was in the town, as usual in Germany, a theater, where opera, op√©ra-comique, operetta, drama, comedy, and vaudeville are presented--every sort of play of every style and fashion. There were performances three times a week from
quoteTime: six to nine in the evening
quoteLast: . Old Jean Michel never missed one, and was equally interested in everything. Once he took his grandson with him.
title: Jean-Christophe, Volume I
author: Rolland, Romain, 1866-1944; Cannan, Gilbert, 1884-1955 [Translator]

quoteFirst: , the nearest part about four leagues distant. After we had anchored, I sent a boat to sound, and the water was found to shoal gradually toward the land. While we lay at anchor, which was from
quoteTime: six to nine in the evening
quoteLast: , we found little or no current, nor could we perceive that the water either rose or fell.
title: A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels, Volume 16
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteFirst: And then comes the great day! The guests are invited to dinner; but they have been enjoined to _come early_, and they come early with a vengeance. They will not come as the guests of night-loving citizens and aristocrats come, at from
quoteTime: six to nine in the evening
quoteLast: ;--no, at ten and eleven in the morning you shall see their faces, that never yet were ashamed of day-light, and that tell of fresh air and early hours. Then come rattling in sundry vehicles with their cargoes of men and women; lively salutations are exchanged; the horses are led away to the stables, and the guests into the house to doff great coats and cloaks, hats and bonnets, and sit down to luncheon.
title: The Rural Life of England
author: Howitt, William, 1792-1879; Bewick, Thomas, 1753-1828 [Illustrator]; Williams, Samuel, 1788-1853 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: as errand running at noon and casual employment in the evening after 7, resulting in hardship to both parents and children; one acknowledged that if he were prevented from employing cheap labor his business would suffer; another said that he employed a boy at noon and also from 5.30 to 9 P.M., the work being light and the parents satisfied, and that the training was good for boys. A fruiterer actually declared that the limit of eight hours on Saturday would make a boy valueless to him; another said he employed a boy for one hour in the morning, from
quoteLast: , and also on Saturday morning and evening, in running errands, and that the work was not heavy; another employed boys after school from 6 to 9.30 P.M., insisting that the work was good for them, as it kept them from the street and gave them an insight into business habits.
title: Child Labor in City Streets
author: Clopper, Edward Nicholas, 1879-1953

title: Beleaguered in Pekin: The Boxer's War Against the Foreigner
author: Coltman, Robert, 1862-1931

quoteFirst: The periodic variation of excitability exhibited here is practically the same as shown by other specimens. The interesting variation is in the character of the recovery from stimulus; the leaf was falling from
quoteLast: ; owing to the shifting of the base-line upwards the recovery appears to be incomplete. After 9 P.M. the leaf was erected, at first slowly, then at a very rapid rate.
title: Life Movements in Plants, Volume I
author: Bose, Jagadis Chandra, 1858-1937

title: Everyman's Land
